Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Evaluating the Feasibility of a fully-automated, on-line, real-time analyzer for simultaneous determination of individual THMs and HAAs
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial impact of this project will be in potentially improving drinking water quality throughout the United States and the world. The availability of a safe drinking water supply is fundamental to human life and the development of stable civilizations. This importance cannot be minimized. Moreover, the disinfection and treatment of drinking water in the United States alone is big business. Currently, plant operators do not have efficient and affordable systems that allow them to do on-site process control. The result is that many water utilities are simply flying blind and hoping that their water meets federal regulations. Our system places them squarely in control of the situation. Our system will provide utilities and researchers a deeper understanding of the trihalomethanes (THMs) and haloacetic acids (HAAs) formation process and enable mitigation strategies. They will be able to be proactive as well as reactive in responding to water quality changes. Eventually, once utilities use our device to establish monitoring programs as part of their quality control and quality assurance, the water treatment plants will be able to save operating expenses by optimizing their treatment chemical usage while also improving water quality parameters.


This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will support the technological development of an innovative device aimed for real-time process control and optimization on-site of THMs and HAAs at municipal water treatment plants. The disinfection drinking water supplies has virtually eliminated waterborne disease in the United States, but produces two classes of disinfection by-products: the THMs and HAAs. The THMs and HAAs are carcinogens and are regulated by the USEPA in drinking water. While the THMs and the HAAs are similar in origin, they have radically different chemical and physical properties. Typically two different analytical instruments or methods are used for their analysis. Our proposed device is innovative; it is a single, device capable of measuring the individual concentrations of each THM and HAA. The research objectives are to determine the feasibility of our proposed device to simultaneously measure the concentrations of the THMs and HAAs in real-time, on-line and on-site at a water treatment plant. The specific technical goals of the study are: adapt the chemistry for automation, determine stability of reagents, and compare to standard United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) methods. Successful completion will demonstrate a prototype capable of analyzing individual THMs and HAAs equivalent to USEPA methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project outcome of this National Science Foundation-Small Business Innovation Research Phase I grant demonstrated the technical feasibility of a fully-automated, on-line and on-site system for analysis of haloacetic acids (HAAs) in drinking water. The HAAs are carcinogenic and a class of drinking water disinfection by-products that are regulated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency.

The intellectual merit of this SBIR project evaluated the technical feasibility of our proposed system – the HAA Rapid Response – a fully-automated, on-line system developed to operate at water treatment plants with minimal operator intervention. In this fashion, the HAA Rapid Response will provide superintendents HAAs concentration data in real-time in tabular and graphic formation. This will enable superintendents to make decisions in real-time to reduce HAAs concentrations in their distribution systems and spend less money doing so through reduction in treatment chemical usage. In the proposed SBIR Phase II, Foundation Instruments will determine the commercial feasibility of the HAA Rapid Response system.

The primary broader impact categories addressed by this SBIR Phase I proposal were: improved well-being of individuals in society; full participation of women in STEM; and increasing partnerships between academia and industry; and increased economic competitiveness of the United States . Well-being of individuals in society will be improved by this project through determining the feasibility of a product (the HAA Rapid Response) that will enable superintendents of drinking water treatment plants to reduce the formation of HAAs (carcinogens) in their water treatment plants and thus distribution systems as well. This reduction will be done through optimization of treatment practices that aim to reduce treatment chemicals and costs needed to produce high quality water. Three doctoral students were funded by this project. All were first generation students. Two were female graduate students, one a doctoral candidate who has recently defended her dissertation and the other a first year student. The first year student will continue working on this project learning instrument development and commercialization skills. The recently graduated student has accepted a position starting in November at a commercial lab as a liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry specialist. The third graduate student funded on this project is expected to join Foundation Instruments in January. This SBIR proposal was instrumental in providing the opportunity to occur. Finally, this SBIR project has provided an avenue for The University of Memphis and Foundation Instruments to work closely together on new intellectual property and work out the procedures and practices for future SBIR or STTR collaborations. Commercialization of technologies developed in Universities is an excellent opportunity to increase the economic competitiveness of the United States and train the future STEM work force in the process. In this case, the HAA Rapid Response is a patented instrument – but a patent does not mean commercially feasible. This SBIR funded research will allow Foundation Instruments to spin the HAA Rapid Response out of the University research laboratory into the real world at drinking water plants in the United States and around the world.
